questions.question: What is digital forensics?
options: The process of creating computer software
The application of computer science and investigative procedures for legal purposes involving digital evidence analysis
The study of computer hardware components
questions.answer: The application of computer science and investigative procedures for legal purposes involving digital evidence analysis

questions.question: What is the main difference between digital forensics and data recovery?
options: Data recovery is always legal, digital forensics is not
Digital forensics retrieves lost data, data recovery analyzes evidence
Data recovery retrieves accidentally deleted information, digital forensics investigates digital evidence for legal purposes
There is no difference between the two
questions.answer: Data recovery retrieves accidentally deleted information, digital forensics investigates digital evidence for legal purposes

questions.question: What are the three components of the investigations triad?
options: Vulnerability assessment, network intrusion detection, and digital investigations
questions.answer: Vulnerability assessment, network intrusion detection, and digital investigations

questions.question: What is case law used for in digital forensics?
options: To apply previous similar cases when statutes don't exist
questions.answer: To apply previous similar cases when statutes don't exist

questions.question: What are the two main categories of digital investigations?
questions.answer: Public-sector and private-sector

questions.question: What act was passed in 1986 that addresses computer-related crimes?
questions.answer: Computer Fraud and Abuse Act

questions.question: What is a DEFR?
questions.answer: Digital Evidence First Responder

questions.question: What document contains a sworn statement of support of facts about evidence of a crime?
questions.answer: Affidavit

questions.question: What policy defines rules for using company computers and networks?
questions.answer: Acceptable use policy

questions.question: What is line of authority in private-sector investigations?
options: Who has legal right to initiate investigations and handle evidence
questions.answer: Who has legal right to initiate investigations and handle evidence

questions.question: What do warning banners on company computer screens accomplish?
options: Inform users the organization can inspect systems and traffic at will
questions.answer: Inform users the organization can inspect systems and traffic at will

questions.question: What does BYOD stand for?
questions.answer: Bring Your Own Device

questions.question: What is the chain of custody?
options: The path evidence takes from discovery until case closure
The locking mechanism on evidence containers
The sequence of commands in forensic software
questions.answer: The path evidence takes from discovery until case closure

questions.question: What is an evidence custody form used for?
options: To document what has been done with evidence and its copies
questions.answer: To document what has been done with evidence and its copies

questions.question: What should be used to secure and catalog digital evidence?
questions.answer: Evidence bags

questions.question: What is the first step in the systematic approach to problem solving in digital forensics?
options: Make an initial assessment about the case type
questions.answer: Make an initial assessment about the case type

questions.question: What three types of situations are common in private-sector investigations?
options: Hardware failure, software bugs, network issues
Abuse of computing assets, email abuse, Internet abuse
questions.answer: Abuse of computing assets, email abuse, Internet abuse

questions.question: What is needed for an Internet abuse investigation?
options: Proxy server logs, suspect computer IP address, disk drive, forensics tools
questions.answer: Proxy server logs, suspect computer IP address, disk drive, forensics tools

questions.question: What is attorney-client privilege (ACP)?
options: The right of attorneys to use any software
The requirement to keep all findings confidential
The ability to bypass search warrants
The permission to access any system
questions.answer: The requirement to keep all findings confidential

questions.question: What is a bit-stream copy?
options: A bit-by-bit copy of the original storage medium
questions.answer: A bit-by-bit copy of the original storage medium

questions.question: What is the first rule of computer forensics?
questions.answer: Preserve the original evidence

questions.question: What devices prevent writing data to evidence drives?
questions.answer: Write-blockers

questions.question: What does FTK stand for?
questions.answer: Forensic Toolkit

questions.question: What should always be maintained during an investigation?
options: A journal to keep notes on actions taken
questions.answer: A journal to keep notes on actions taken
